meanings.definition: To make a hole in something using a tool
meanings.sent1: I used a drill to bore a hole in the wood.
meanings.sent2: The construction worker bore through the concrete with a jackhammer.
meanings.sent3: The squirrel tried to bore a hole in the bird feeder to get the seeds.
meanings.sent4: The miner bore deep into the earth searching for precious minerals.
meanings.sent5: The artist used a special tool to bore intricate patterns into the metal.

meanings.definition: To make someone feel uninterested or annoyed
meanings.sent1: The long lecture began to bore the students.
meanings.sent2: The repetitive tasks at work can bore me sometimes.
meanings.sent3: The movie's slow pace started to bore the audience to sleep.
meanings.sent4: Her constant complaints bore her friends, and they stopped listening.
meanings.sent5: The dry presentation managed to bore even the most attentive listeners.

meanings.definition: A person who talks too much about uninteresting topics
meanings.sent1: He is such a bore at parties, always talking about the stock market.
meanings.sent2: The office bore never fails to bring up the weather in every conversation.
meanings.sent3: The history bore droned on about ancient battles for hours.
meanings.sent4: She avoided sitting next to the bore at dinner parties to escape the dull stories.
meanings.sent5: The science bore could talk endlessly about physics theories no one understood.
